IMO poetry should be enjoyed lyrically *and* in its original meaning, for the former you must know the language and for the latter the translator should keep the original meaning as much a possible.
@caryoscelus: i totally agree, in fact we can enjoy different translations in itself, we can enjoy the abilities and the peculiarity/fancy of different translators.

i have the same issue when translating to and from English, i'm not good at it but practicing really improved my understanding. later on i was able to check on my mistakes, ask for help online and learn little by little, i really enjoyed the whole process but in small quantities.

>i just started to wonder, why do something that many people can do better with less effort? Just because nobody actually does it?

i did some translations (mostly subtitles) because nobody else was doing it. but apart from that i also think that translating can easily be a hobby, specially while learning other languages.

i remember that i wanted to watch a 80's Japanese tv show "Abunai Deka" but couldn't find subtitles, and many others actually... i imagine that "many" people want to watch, read and listen to stuff that hasn't been translated yet.

@caryoscelus: 
>On the other hand, "many" people are interested in anything, it's just the matter of making them aware of that ;) Or, in other words, matter of finding them

very good point.

>I'd be happy to make sub translation (much easier language, usually), but i don't find promoting copyrighted works a good thing

totally agree, i mean, if it has an educational value its a plus.

huh maybe, but i think it depends much more on the environment. i think likes and dislikes disincentivize engagement depending on the type of community.

however i don't think being able to dislike is going to make a person simple click on dislike instead of saying what they want to say, i can only speak for myself.

so maybe, but not proportionally.

@caryoscelus: 
>By proportionally i meant that proportion of negative to positive comments will be higher than in a system with either both likes&dislikes or none

i see, i thought you are talking about the ratio of dislikes/negative comments. were you?

about idiotic statements, i get what you are saying but how does that relate to likes/dislikes?

@caryoscelus: sure and i agree that technology in turn shapes the community who uses it. zerome for instance, is pretty good for what is trying to be right know, which is censorship resistant. however likes/dislikes may be desirable elsewhere.

@caryoscelus: absolutely, hopefully people would flock out to other forums like zerovoat, *shrieks* millchan, etc. nonetheless this would create a demand for more communities and they would likely appear to attend the demand.
@caryoscelus: yeah that is desirable, maybe it will happen, maybe not but a parody of 'classical' internet isn't exactly bad, right? reddit is cool, deviantart is cool, discourse is cool...

the highlights suggest something metallic or an artificial light being cast upon. there seems to be some sort of extrusion somewhere in the middle of it. it looks curved (highlights and shadows suggests that)
@caryoscelus: i will contradict myself, i was elaborating, read to the very end (sorry for not making it more concise and short).

@caryoscelus: for the terminology:
first assumption is the existence of multiverses, since our universe was created.

particular configuration = our particular universe configuration (quantum states, particles, gravity, open/closed, etc).
 
about "everything", context:
> as everything must happen eventually **(lets assume that is true for our universe)**

*our universe* (random fluctuations predict that, but that is not important to the argument)

>one may argue that everything needs moments to occur but its hard to argue that these moments are similar to time

everything here refers to the idea of how humans see processes in general, outside any boundaries, our mind is attached to the idea of before...after, so for us to rationalized how things occur we must use some word, we use 'time' but time has a scientific context and its configuration is particular to our universe, we don't know how time is on other universes.

@caryoscelus:
>From my pov, there's no way phenomenal (as opposed to "functional") consciousness can arise from something that isn't it

expand on this.

would it be fair to say that you subscribe to cartesianism? (the doubt everything part)

>And this is exactly an example of that. If physics says our "universe" has some properties we find unappealing, we may invent some unfalsifiable construct which would say our "world" still keeps the properties we see fit for it

there is whole debate about shift in paradigm but that is not really relevant to what science may reveal, time and gravity are still mysteries and as mentioned, the very idea of a big bang may very well suggest that it may happen elsewhere with completely different configuration.

 

i only brought that up to break apart our conception about time, its obviously unimportant to us what happens in other universes since we are locked to ours.

that is tricky but i think it would be ok to do so, its like that saying "I have a bridge to sell you" except that youtube is implicitly buying your usage of the bridge, no one is selling it away.

@caryoscelus: i think so, you can't legally give away something that it doesn't belong to you, period. by uploading to youtube you are agreeing to an invalid contract since you don't have the rights, so its void, you aren't the one holding the contract trying to give away rights you don't have.

youtube however wants rights to reuse the material in any way it sees fit so the added value you brought to the material in question (i think) youtube can use it.

for instance, lets say you post a comment on youtube containing a reasonably large text excerpt that is copyrighted, youtube still wants to reuse that content in any way it sees fit. i think its impossible to enforce that without sounding borderline authoritarian.

if its legal or not is to be determined i think. but all things considered its best to avoid using youtube, if the creator of the material doesn't like that youtube has reused its material it would be very impractical for the creator to issue a lawsuit.

@caryoscelus: i see, that may be problematic, to truly stream through zeronet means using something like peermessage, and you'd probably need NAT traversal or a server to supply many peers (assuming most are behind a NAT). on the top of my head, otherwise it would be just a zite streaming through http from a server, which you can do with obs by streaming via rtmp. do you have an specific setup already?
